title: Power - constant velocity up different inclines

content.description: In Scenario <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> an object is pulled at a constant speed on a ramp that is tilted at an angle <math alttext="theta sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>θ</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math> above the horizontal as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. Frictional forces between the object and the ramp are negligible. In Scenario <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, the incline of the ramp is increased to a larger angle <math alttext="theta sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>θ</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="theta sub 1 is less than theta sub 2, which is less than 90 degrees" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>θ</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mi>θ</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo><</mo><mn>90</mn><mtext>°</mtext></mstyle></math> as shown in Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>. The object continues to be pulled at the same constant speed. How will the power developed by the force pulling the box, <math alttext="P sub pull" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>P</mi><mi>pull</mi></msub></mstyle></math> and the power developed by the normal force <math alttext="P sub normal" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>P</mi><mi>norm</mi></msub></mstyle></math> change between <math alttext="theta sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>θ</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="theta sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>θ</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mstyle></math>?
content.question: <math alttext="P sub pull" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>P</mi><mi>pull</mi></msub></mstyle></math><math alttext="P sub normal" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>P</mi><mi>norm</mi></msub></mstyle></math>AIncreasesDecreasesBIncreasesRemains the sameCRemains the sameDecreasesDRemains the sameRemains the same

skill.text: 2.C: Compare physical quantities between two or more scenarios or at different times and locations in a single scenario.
